Re ''Rising Waters, and Sinking Hearts, in New Jersey'' (front page, Aug. 15):
The reasons for the flooding that persists in New Jersey and recurs year after year can be answered through basic geological reasoning.

The locations most prone to flooding are those areas that are most built up. Homes and businesses constructed adjacent to a creek or a river create an impervious layer so that rainwater cannot seep into the ground. Watersheds where blacktop has replaced soil and grass can quickly fill with a raging flow of high water once the natural channel has been reduced to a fraction of its natural width.

I am not making light of the tragedy that people are facing, but I would like to remind developers, town planners and home builders to think about the geology of an area and discontinue overdevelopment in watersheds.
The writer is a geographic information system specialist at Vassar College.
